I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   In September 2011, the Government of the Philippines, through its Climate Change 
Commission (CCC), requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to conduct a pilot study on the Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape,1 as a 
demonstration site for the eco-town framework as espoused in the National Climate Change 
Action Plan, 2011–2028 (NCCAP).2 An eco-town is a planning unit comprising a group of 
municipalities located within and around the boundaries of critical biodiversity areas, and is used 
as an implementation vehicle for the convergence of adaptation and mitigation actions, and for 
demonstration of an integrated ecosystem-based management approach. The proposed TA3 
seeks to pursue strategies for climate resilience and green growth in the Upper Marikina River 
Basin  Protected  Landscape  for  effective  integration  of  climate  change  concerns  into 
development plans at the level of local government units (LGUs) to reap multiple benefits in 
terms of environmental sustainability, job creation, and long-term economic growth. 
 
2.   A series of meetings took place from October 2011 to February 2012 between CCC and 
ADB to clarify the outcomes and outputs of the proposed TA. CCC held additional consultations 
with local stakeholders during this period. ADB circulated a draft TA concept paper for comment 
by government departments and other stakeholders. A consensus emerged on the need to 
demonstrate the eco-town framework in the Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape. 
Following a fact-finding mission, a memorandum of understanding was signed with the vice-
chair of CCC on 22 May 2012, agreeing to the core elements of the TA (impact, outcome, 
outputs, cost, financing, implementation arrangements, and the consultant terms of reference). 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Philippines is highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The country is 
ranked highest in the world in terms of vulnerability to tropical cyclones and third in terms of the 
population’s  exposure  to  floods  and  droughts.4 The  National  Economic  and  Development 
Authority estimated that economic losses from typhoons, floods, and landslides in 2011 equaled 
P59.2 billion. Enhancing the climate resilience of the economy and the adaptive capacity of the 
populations is thus crucial for sustainable development. 
 
4.  Climate change-induced economic losses are particularly high in urban and peri-urban 
areas largely because of the increasing fragility of urban ecosystems and the low adaptive 
capacity of communities. The need to develop ecologically stable and economically resilient 
urban areas or ―eco-towns‖ has been recognized but the concept has not been demonstrated. 
 
5.  To address climate change, the government enacted the Climate Change Act of 2009 
(Republic Act 9729), which established the CCC as the government’s sole policy-making body 
tasked  with  coordinating, monitoring,  and  evaluating  programs  and  action  plans  related  to 
climate change. The Climate Change Act provided the principles guiding the formulation of 
NCCAP, which prioritizes food security, water sufficiency, ecosystem and environmental stability, 
human  security,  climate-smart  industries  and  services,  sustainable  energy,  and  capacity 
                                                
1  Proclamation No. 296 of 24 Nov. 2011, issued by the President of the Philippines, defines the Upper Marikina River 
Basin Protected Landscape as covering the Marikina watershed reservation situated in the city of Antipolo, and the 
four municipalities of Baras, Rodriguez, San Mateo, and Tanay in the province of Rizal.  
2  Climate Change Commission. 2011. National Climate Change Action Plan 2011–2028. Manila. (p. 43) 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 18 May 2012. 
4  Climate Change Commission. 2010. National Framework Strategy on Climate Change 2010–2022. Manila.

2   
development.    The  NCCAP  is  based  on  the  building  of  eco-towns  at  the  local  level. 
Demonstration of the eco-town framework, through implementing priority climate resilience and 
green growth measures, is expected to not only address the impacts of climate change on 
communities but also bring about sustainable development and poverty reduction benefits. 
 
6.  The TA seeks to pursue strategies for green growth and climate resilience in the Upper 
Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape. The area was chosen because of its (i) high bio-
physical vulnerability to climate change impacts; (ii) high levels of urban poverty and population 
density with settlements in vulnerable locations; and (iii) high demonstration potential to the rest 
of the country, in terms of mainstreaming climate resilience and green growth, and eco-town 
development.  
 
7.   The TA has strong links to the Philippines Development Plan, 2011–2016,5 especially 
with regard to goal 3 (enhanced resilience of natural systems and improved adaptive capacities 
of human communities to cope with environmental hazards, including climate-related risks) of 
the strategic framework for conservation, protection, and rehabilitation of the environment and 
natural resources. The TA has robust linkage to ADB’s country partnership strategy 2011–2016 
and  its  thematic  assessment  paper  on  climate  change  and  disaster  risk  reduction,6 which 
recognises the urgent need to increase the resilience of the Philippines to climate change and 
natural  disasters  while  harnessing  opportunities  for  greenhouse  gas  (GHG)  mitigation.  In 
addition to contributing to the objective of strengthening the capacity of national and local 
institutions, the TA closely aligns with ADB’s Strategy 2020,7 Southeast Asia Department’s 
climate change implementation plan,8 and various sector assessments, strategies, and road 
maps in terms of increasing resilience to climate stresses (agriculture and natural resources 
sector), promoting use of renewable energy (energy sector), and enhancing water sanitation 
through effective waste management (urban development sector).  
  
8.   The TA builds on vulnerability assessment methodologies developed under the ADB-
funded regional TA on adaptation9 and disaster risk reduction projects undertaken in Manila and 
other  areas.  It  will  promote  synergies  with  ADB  lending  programs  such  as  the  proposed 
Integrated  Natural  Resources  and  Environmental  Management  project,  aimed  at  restoring 
critical watersheds in four upper river basins. The TA will benefit from other climate change 
projects funded by the German Agency for International Cooperation, the Global Green Growth 
Institute,  and  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development.  The  TA  is  considered 
essential, however, as the eco-town framework has not yet been demonstrated in the Upper 
Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact is enhanced climate resilience and green growth in the Upper 
Marikina  River  Basin  Protected  Landscape.  Improvements  in  resilience  will  be  monitored

6  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Philippines, 2011–2016. Manila; the thematic assessment is available as

3 
through (i) a reduction in exposure to flooding and landslides (with a target of 15% reduction in 
losses by 2022 from the 2012 baseline); and (ii) an increase in (a) adaptive capacity through 
improved  income  levels  of  vulnerable  communities,  including  women;  and  (b)  the  amount 
budgeted for climate change and disaster preparedness by LGUs (with a target of 15% increase 
from the 2012 baseline).  
 
10.   The expected outcome is that by the end of TA, LGUs in the Upper Marikina River Basin 
Protected Landscape have increased capacity to mainstream climate resilient and green growth 
options  in  development  plans,  programs,  policies,  and/or  projects.  The  capacity  to  bring 
together the concepts of low-carbon development, resource efficiency and adaptation to climate 
change will be strengthened. By doing so, LGUs can significantly contribute to the achievement 
of the Millennium Development Goals, especially with regard to poverty alleviation (goal 1) and 
environmental sustainability (goal 7). Demonstration of the eco-town framework will advance the 
pursuit of green growth and reduce the impacts of climate change on communities, while also 
contributing to sustainable urban development and poverty reduction. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The proposed TA includes (i) creation of a ―green growth road map‖ for the Upper 
Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape based on local circumstances, political leadership, 
the capacity for change, and the needs and priorities of stakeholders; (ii) preparation of an 
inventory of GHG emissions, assessment of vulnerability to climate change, and economic 
valuation of ecosystem services; (iii) identification and prioritization of interventions to adapt to 
the impacts of climate change and trigger green growth; (iv) development of local climate 
change  action  plans that  can  be  integrated  into  comprehensive  development  plans  of  the 
concerned LGUs; and (v) piloting of selected green growth and resilience measures. The TA will 
consider five dimensions relevant to green growth—(i) economic development; (ii) resilience to 
climate change; (iii) biodiversity, ecosystems, and social development; (iv) GHG emissions 
reductions; and (v) poverty alleviation—in the delivery of the following four outputs.  
 
12.   Output 1: Collection of baseline information, and assessment of vulnerability to 
climate change. This output is aimed at stocktaking and vision setting based on consultations 
with diverse stakeholders, including vulnerable communities, and women. The baseline will be 
defined to illustrate the business-as-usual path for economic growth, environmental quality, and 
social development in the absence of climate change measures. Baseline will be determined 
through (i) data collection; (ii) review of development plans and literature; (iii) survey of  local 
institutions, governments, and businesses; (iv) vulnerability assessment (including likely future 
climate change scenarios and localized impacts);  (v) economic valuation of natural resources 
and ecosystem services; and (vi) GHG emission inventory. Scenario setting will be conducted to 
project future trends in usage of the natural resources and their associated impacts. To the 
extent possible, the GHG emissions inventory at the LGU level will be prepared following the 
global protocol for community-scale GHG emissions.10  
 
13.   Output  2:  Identification,  analysis,  and  prioritization  of  locally  appropriate 
adaptation and mitigation measures. This output aims to identify measures with the most 
significant impact across the five dimensions relevant to green growth. A menu of options will be 
developed by first preparing an inventory of climate change adaptation and mitigation measures 
                                                
10  ICLEI-Local  Governments  for  Sustainability  and  C40  Cities  Climate  Leadership  Group  published  a  draft 
community protocol for GHG emissions. Source: http://www.iclei.org/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Global/ 
Progams/GHG/GPC_Draft_ Document.pdf

4   
based on best practices in the Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape, within the 
Philippines and at regional and global levels.  A short list of options will then be prepared on the 
basis  of  feedback  from  stakeholders—including  vulnerable  communities,  women,  and  the 
private sector—on the feasibility of implementing such measures. A multi-criteria cost-benefit 
analysis will be used to assess the business-as-usual scenario and proposed measures to 
establish potential outcomes across the five dimensions relevant to green growth. 
 
14.   Output 3: Selection of pilot demonstration areas and implementation of gender-
equitable  adaptation  and  mitigation  measures.  Based  on  specific  criteria,  sites  will  be 
chosen to implement priority adaptation and GHG mitigation measures such as promoting 
renewable energy, forest rehabilitation and reforestation, and creation of alternative livelihoods 
focusing on sustainable management of natural resources. The primary focus of the TA will be 
on non-structural measures, although a few cost-effective structural measures may be piloted. 11 
LGUs will implement such measures by involving local communities including vulnerable groups, 
women and the private sector. Community-based activities that improve climate resilience and 
livelihood diversification of women, children, and marginalized groups will be prioritized.  
 
15.   Output 4: Development of knowledge products and strengthening of stakeholder 
capacity. This output is aimed at (i) disseminating the TA findings to decision-makers from the 
government, industry, and civil society through workshops and seminars; (ii) documenting the 
process for future reference of stakeholders in demonstrating the eco-town framework in other 
areas; (iii) preparing local climate change action plans and guidelines for effective integration of 
climate change concerns in development plans; and (iv) strengthening  the capacity of key 
stakeholders (including women and the private sector) in vulnerability assessment, economic 
analyses, and piloting of climate change actions. Knowledge products will be developed on the 
basis of an iterative learning process to reflect on-the-ground experiences and realities.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Climate  Change  Fund. 12   The government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in the form  of 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented for 2 years from 1 October 2012 to 30 September 2014. 
ADB will be the executing agency. CCC will be the implementing agency, in close collaboration 
with the Protected Area Management Board, LGUs in the Upper Marikina River Basin Protected 
Landscape, and other agencies such as the Department of Environment and Natural Resources 
and the Department of Interior and Local Government.  
 
                                                
11 Structural  measures  include  any  physical construction  to  reduce  or avoid possible impacts  of  hazards,  or 
application of engineering techniques to achieve hazard-resistance and resilience in structures or systems. 
Nonstructural measures are any measures not involving physical construction that uses knowledge, practice or 
agreement to reduce risks and impacts, in particular through policies and laws, public awareness raising, training 
and education. United Nations Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction (UNISDR). 2009. UNISDR 
Terminology  on  Disaster  Risk  Reduction.  Geneva,  p.  28.  (http://www.preventionweb.net/files/7817_UNISDR 
TerminologyEnglish.pdf) 
12   Established by ADB.

5 
18.   The TA will finance an estimated 64 person-months of national consultant inputs (for six 
consultants,  in  the  areas  of  climate  change  adaptation,  mitigation,  natural  resources 
management, capacity building and gender mainstreaming, geographic information systems 
and multimedia), to be engaged through a consulting firm in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based 
selection method (90:10) and simplified technical proposal procedures will be followed. The 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Procurement and disbursement will be 
done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) 
and ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). For surveys including baseline data collection and demonstrations, an advance payment 
facility may be used.  
 
19.  CCC  will  be  responsible  for  coordination  and  implementation  of  all  TA  activities, 
including effective monitoring of the work progress of consultants. CCC will assign a senior staff 
member as the focal person to coordinate project activities and delivery outputs of the TA. CCC 
will  also  designate  an  alternate  staff  member  to  assist  the  focal  person.  ADB  will  accept 
consulting firm’s claims upon receipt of a CCC endorsement certifying that work was done 
satisfactorily for the period, with the corresponding progress reports attached.   
 
20.  CCC will serve as the focal organization among involved LGUs and national agencies. 
CCC will organize a project technical working group comprising representatives from Protected 
Area  Management  Board,  LGUs  in  the  Upper  Marikina  River  Basin  Protected  Landscape, 
agencies  such  as  the  Department  of  Environment  and  Natural  Resources,  Department  of 
Interior and Local Government, Department of Energy, Department of Science and Technology, 
Department  of  Transportation  and  Communications,  National  Disaster  Risk  Reduction  and 
Management Council, academia, civil society organizations and the private sector. All LGUs in 
the Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape will be involved in capacity building and 
piloting specific climate actions. CCC will work with the LGUs in the formulation, signage, and 
implementation of the memorandum of agreement between CCC and the LGUs stipulating that 
(i) CCC will provide the necessary technical and financial support from ADB; while (ii) the LGUs 
will provide free access to data, information and facilities, ensure safety and security of the 
project personnel, and facilitate effective coordination among stakeholders in implementation of 
the local climate change action plans and demonstration of the eco-town framework.  
 
21.   Progress of the TA will be monitored using intended outcomes and outputs described in 
the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). With support from the consulting firm, CCC 
will submit quarterly progress reports to ADB. CCC will monitor project progress in accordance 
with  the  project  implementation  schedule,  and  will  keep  ADB  informed  of  any  significant 
deviations from the schedule. Within 3 months of the TA’s completion, CCC will submit a project 
completion report to ADB. The form and content of the reports will be agreed upon by ADB and 
CCC during the TA inception mission.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.   The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the Philippines for Climate Resilience and Green Growth in the Upper Marikina 
River Basin Protected Landscape – Demonstrating the Eco-town Framework, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

a    Established by the Asian Development Bank; the Government of the Philippines, through the Climate 
Change Commission, will provide in-kind contributions in the form of office space, counterpart staff and 
other services. 
b    Includes the cost of computers, printers and geographic information system software. Items will be turned 
over to the implementing agency upon technical assistance project completion.  
c    Includes participation in local and regional climate change events for information exchange and sharing. 
d  Surveys include collection of baseline data (hydro-meteorological, socio-economic and environmental 
including  greenhouse  gas  emissions)  and  community-based  green  growth  and  climate  resilience 
measures at the local government unit level.  
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10    Appendix 3     
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  impacts  of  climate  change  on  the  Philippine  economy,  environment  and 
communities  are  projected  to  be  profoundly  adverse.   The Government  of  the  Philippines 
enacted the Climate Change Act of 2009, which stipulated the creation of the Climate Change 
Commission (CCC) and the establishment of a policy  framework and strategic program to 
address climate change proactively. The National Climate Change Action Plan (NCCAP) for 
2011–2028 identifies key actions.  The plan’s implementation is anchored at the local level 
through the building of ecologically stable and economically resilient towns, or eco-towns. The 
technical assistance (TA) is aimed at demonstrating the eco-town framework in the Upper 
Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape and strengthening the capacity of local government 
units (LGUs) for mainstreaming green, climate resilient growth options in development planning.  
 
2.  The TA will require six national consultants for an estimated 64 person-months of inputs, 
to be engaged through a consulting firm in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The detailed terms of reference are given 
below. The firm will also provide support in the form of one administrative and two technical 
project assistants to assist the LGUs, CCC (implementing agency of the TA) and the national 
consultants. The assistants, under the overall guidance of consulting team leader and the CCC 
focal person, will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)   assist with collecting information, literature, and other documents relevant to the 
TA and in developing databases to support TA activities;  
(ii)   manage  the  logistics  of  and  coordinate  content  development  for  meetings, 
training events, and other TA-related activities;  
(iii)   assist with the development and dissemination of TA products and reports;  
(iv)   assist in arranging official review missions and make appointments with the TA 
stakeholders for the prompt and effective implementation of the project activities;  
(v)   assist LGUs and the project team in monitoring of project activities;  
(vi)   assist in the preparation and timely submission of consolidated progress reports, 
annual project implementation review reports and other monitoring reports;  
(vii)   assist the project team to conduct a post-completion analysis of the project;  
(viii)   assist in various administrative and forwarding procedures including maintenance 
of project information;  
(ix)  provide support in the implementation and delivery of TA outputs; and  
(x)   perform other activities deemed necessary within the framework of the TA. 
 
3.  The quality- and cost-based selection method (90:10) and simplified technical proposal 
procedures will be followed for selection of the consulting firm.  Procurement and disbursement 
will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time) and ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). Items procured under the TA will be turned over to the implementing agency upon TA 
completion.  Progress  of  the  TA  will  be  monitored  using  intended  outcomes  and  outputs 
described in the design and monitoring framework. The consulting firm  will assist CCC in 
submitting quarterly progress reports to ADB. The form and content of the reports will be agreed 
upon by ADB and CCC during the TA inception mission.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  Detailed Terms of Reference  
 
4.   Team leader and climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction specialist    
(12 person-months, intermittent). The consultant will have at least 8 years of experience in 
climate  change-related  work  with  a  relevant  master’s  or  higher  degree  in  environmental 
management, climate change, or a related discipline. The specialist will have experience as 
team leader and in assisting government institutions. The ability to work with governments (at 
the national and local levels), development partners and civil society in building sustainable 
capacity to address climate change and to report effectively in strategic consultations and in 
written reports is also required. Specific duties include:  
 
(i)   manage  the  consulting  team  and  take  overall  responsibility  for  ensuring 
production and delivery of quality outputs (inception report, quarterly progress 
reports, and final report);  
(ii)   lead the stocktaking process on greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation, adaptation, 
and disaster risk-reduction initiatives in the upper Marikina river basin and assist 
stakeholders in mapping out a shared vision for a green growth;  
(iii)   coordinate  the  team’s  technical  outputs,  including  baseline  identification, 
assessment of vulnerabilities and impacts, climate change scenarios, and the 
selection  and  monitoring  of  the  effectiveness  of  adaptation  and  mitigation 
measures, including economic analysis;  
(iv)   oversee preparation of a road map based on eco-town framework and identify 
climate change-related investments up to 2025;  
(v)   undertake consultations with key stakeholders—including LGU authorities, the 
private sector, and vulnerable communities—to validate climate change actions 
(e.g., renewable energy, energy efficiency, reforestation, low carbon transport, 
waste management, water conservation, flood control, disaster risk reduction, 
biodiversity  protection,  sustainable  agriculture,  and  climate  proofing  of 
infrastructure);  
(vi)   ensure  effective  implementation  of  selected  adaptation  measures,  with  due 
consideration to environmental and social safeguards, national agencies and 
LGU regulations, and other compliance requirements; and  
(vii)   coordinate awareness raising and capacity strengthening activities, such as:  
 
(a)   preparation of a green growth road map based on eco-town framework, 
drawing on the best practices, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate 
Change and national assessments, and other publications;  
(b)   preparation of climate change action plans and operational guidelines for 
integrating adaptation concerns in local development plans of LGUs;  
(c)   development  of  training  materials  such  as  guidebooks  on  adaptation 
(e.g., mainstreaming climate risk management in the upper Marikina river 
basin);  
(d)   implementation of an awareness raising campaign on green growth, eco-
town framework, and organization of seminars and workshops; and 
(e)   dissemination of the TA findings in various local, national, regional and 
international forums on climate change and by using public meetings and 
focus group discussions with community leaders and media. 
 
5.  Climate change mitigation specialist (12 person-months, intermittent). The consultant 
will have a master’s or higher degree in environmental science, management or policy, climate 
change, or a related area, with a minimum of 4 years experience in GHG inventories, mitigation

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
projects and watershed management. Experience in preparing project design documents for the 
Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) and in implementing various steps of the CDM project 
cycle and knowledge of reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD+) 
is an advantage. Also required is the ability to work with governments (at both national and local 
levels),  development  partners  and  other  stakeholders  in  building  sustainable  capacity  to 
address climate change and to report effectively in consultations and in written reports. Specific 
duties include:  
 
(i)   provide inputs to the inception and quarterly progress reports;  
(ii)   review  national  documents  on  climate  change,  including  national 
communications  to  the  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate 
Change, and compile information on mitigation policies and measures;  
(iii)   assess the technical and institutional needs and capacities  to address GHG 
mitigation in the upper Marikina river basin and develop a capacity building action 
plan with a focus on policy makers, private sector and local communities;  
(iv)   conduct  consultations  with  decision  makers  and  technical  staff  of  national 
agencies,  LGUs,  and  local  communities  (including  women  and  indigenous 
people)  to  assess  GHG  mitigation  priorities,  and  identify  key  policies  and 
measures for implementation in the upper Marikina river basin;  
(v)   identify  locally  appropriate  GHG  mitigation  measures  that  can  benefit  from 
international carbon markets;  
(vi)   ensure  effective  implementation  of  selected  mitigation  measures,  with  due 
consideration to environmental and social safeguards, national agencies and 
LGU regulations, and other compliance requirements; and 
(vii)  organize information dissemination and capacity strengthening activities such as:  
(a)   prepare action plans for GHG mitigation and capacity building specific to 
the upper Marikina river basin;  
(b)   develop operational guidelines for integrating mitigation into the green 
growth road map of the upper Marikina river basin;  
(c)   develop  training  materials  and  organizing  seminars  on  market 
mechanisms (such as CDM and REDD+); and  
(d)   disseminate  the  TA  findings  in  various  local,  national,  regional  and 
international forums on climate change and by using public meetings and 
focus group discussions with community leaders and media. 
 
6.  Natural  resource  management  specialist  (10  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
consultant will have a relevant master’s or higher degree in natural resource management, 
climate change, or a related area, with a minimum of 4 years experience in economics, resource 
valuation or a related field. Experience in economic modeling is a strong advantage. Also 
required is the ability to work with governments (at both national and local levels), development 
partners and other stakeholders and to report effectively in strategic consultations and in written 
reports. Specific duties include:  
 
(i)   provide inputs to the inception and quarterly progress reports;  
(ii)   serve as a land use planning expert for the team and provide technical inputs;  
(iii)   undertake modeling and related cost–benefit analyses of potential measures;  
(iv)   assist in consultations with LGUs to assess priorities for mitigation and adaptation 
investments in the upper Marikina river basin;  
(v)   provide technical inputs for the green growth road map; and  
(vi)   assist in information dissemination and capacity strengthening activities.

Appendix 3  13 
 
7.  Capacity  building  and  gender  mainstreaming  specialist  (10  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will have a master’s or higher degree in environmental policy, social 
development, or a related area, with at least 5 years of experience in the capacity building 
aspects of climate change. The specialist will be well versed in gender mainstreaming aspects. 
The  specialist  will  have  good  facilitation  and  networking  skills  to  work  effectively  with 
governments  (at  both  the  national  and  local  levels),  development  partners  and  other 
stakeholders.  The  consultant  will  have  excellent  organizational  and  presentation  skills  and 
strong interpersonal skills with the ability to promote participation and team work. The consultant 
will be proficient in English with the ability to prepare reports independently. Specifically, the 
consultant will:  
 
(i)   provide inputs to the inception and quarterly progress reports;  
(ii)   review relevant documents and conduct consultations with decision makers and 
technical staff in relevant agencies and LGUs to assess human and institutional 
capacities for mainstreaming climate change concerns into local development 
plans in the Marikina river basin;  
(iii)   assess and prioritize capacity needs, and prepare a capacity building action plan;  
(iv)   develop an action plan to effectively integrate gender concerns in the formulation 
and implementation of climate resilience and green growth measures; indicators 
include reference to gender or gender equality in project documents, gender 
needs and vulnerability assessments, the extent of engagement with women’s 
organizations or groups, the number of targeted women beneficiaries and women 
in project staff management, and the use of gender disaggregated data;  
(v)   assist in implementing gender-equitable adaptation and mitigation measures; and  
(vi)  lead  other  experts  in  information  dissemination  and  capacity  strengthening 
activities, such as:  
 
(a)   implementation  of  a  capacity  building  action  plan  for  climate  change 
adaptation and mitigation specific to the upper Marikina river basin;  
(b)  preparation of training materials for integrating mitigation and adaptation 
concerns in local development plans, and guidebooks and manuals on 
green growth and resilience measures specific to the upper Marikina river 
basin;  
(c)  organizing  seminars  and  workshops  on  market  mechanisms  such  as 
CDM and REDD+, and climate resilience; and  
(d)   dissemination of the TA findings in various local, national, regional and 
international forums on climate change and by using public meetings and 
focus group discussions with community leaders and media.  
 
8.  Geographic  information  systems  specialist  (10  person-months,  intermittent). The 
geographic  information  system  (GIS)  specialist  will  have  at  least  5  years  experience  in 
applications in natural resource management with a relevant degree in information technology, 
engineering, or a related area. Knowledge of GIS hardware, software, and data systems and the 
skills to provide advanced advice, training, and consultation with respect to GIS and Global 
Positioning System technology is required to ensure the latest developments in the field are 
incorporated in the work processes. Knowledge of database management systems—including 
data standards, data structure, data management, relational database theory, and spatial data 
to capture and produce needed resource information—is required. Familiarity with 3-D mapping 
and remote sensing technologies is desirable. The specialist will have a strong command of

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
spoken and written English, and the ability to prepare reports independently. Specific duties 
include:  
 
(i)   provide inputs to the inception and quarterly progress reports;  
(ii)   perform as an information coordinator for the project, which involves acquiring, 
coordinating, and maintaining a comprehensive spatial information database for 
the  upper  Marikina  river  basin  in  collaboration  with  the  Protected  Area 
Management Board, to meet LGU information management needs;  
(iii)   serve as a technical specialist in the use of GIS to support climate change and 
resource management planning efforts;  
(iv)   liaise with national agencies and LGU representatives to obtain required data;  
(v)   develop  agreed GIS methodologies to map  climate change  vulnerability  and 
impacts and other relevant information;  
(vi)   work with natural resource management specialist in preparing land use plans; 
and  
(vii)   in collaboration with the capacity building and gender mainstreaming specialist, 
develop  awareness  raising  and  training  programs  to  support  institutional 
strengthening for climate change action in the upper Marikina river basin. 
 
9.  Multimedia  specialist  (10  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist  will  have  an 
advanced degree in information technology and knowledge management and at least 3 years of 
experience  in  the  development  and  implementation  of  information  systems  and  websites. 
Knowledge  of  the  latest  desktop  publishing,  video  production,  and  animation  software  is 
desirable. The expert will also have a strong sense of user interfaces and website usability for 
the intended users. Specific tasks include:  
 
(i)   maintain  and  update  the  project  website,  including  content  management, 
research, design, and implementation of site improvements;  
(ii)   develop original reports, stories, findings, graphics, and images from project data 
sets that will be of interest to the media and resonate with targeted audiences of 
the project;  
(iii)   design  and  implement  a  multimedia  based  awareness-raising  campaign  on 
climate change impacts in the upper Marikina river basin;  
(iv)   produce content for the web and mainstream media outlets (TV and print);  
(v)   prepare project-related brochures and flyers, edit and proofread project-related 
communications, and maintain a photo library, video logs and other documents;  
(vi)   manage, analyze, and translate large data sets into strong scientifically grounded 
findings that are of keen interest to the media; and 
(vii)   assist the TA team in preparing various materials for information dissemination 
and capacity strengthening activities.
